messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Excuse me. Boleh awak bilang saya how to get started using these machines?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Of course. Awak member baru di sini?

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: No, I don't. So I need some help.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Well, first it is important to go through a good stretch. You must warm up properly so that you don't hurt yourself on the machines.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Yes, itu saya tahu. Derek just led me through the warm up in the aerobics room. So I'm ready, aku rasa. I can start using the machines.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Alright. Great. Then we must get a card untuk awak.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: What do you mean--a membership card? Saya dah ada.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: No. Not that. I mean a training card. The card allows you to keep track of how much weight you use on each machine. Here, let me show you.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Now, you can see that on this card there are all the machines listed. So, when you go through the series of twelve machines, you enter in the number of repetitions you do. And you also enter in the weight at which you set the machine.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: I see. So card ini tolong saya keep track of my progress.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Yes. And it also reminds you what is a suitable weight for each machine. Today, I will go through the machines with you one by one. I will show you how to use them. And we will determine what is a good starting weight for you.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: So you write your name and member number at the top of the card. Lepas tu, after you exercise each time, you file the card kat sini.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Great. Why don't we start on the machines?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Are you alright? Awak boleh buat lebih?

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: I'm sorry. I know there are still seven machines. But I'm exhausted.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: That's okay. Don't worry. It's important not to push yourself. Especially not at the beginning.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Saya boleh buat apa though? I don't know the proper settings for the rest of the machines.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: We can just go through them next time. It's no problem. Really. The most important thing is to know your limits. So if you feel burned out now, it is good to stop. Because if you strain a muscle or hurt your back, then you won't be able to exercise for a couple weeks. Right?

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Yes. I suppose lebih bagus untuk berhenti

summary: #Person1# is a new member who wants to use the machines. Johnson teaches #Person1# to get a card to keep track of the progress and record the suitable weight for each machine. #Person1# stops training as Johnson suggests and will go through the rest of the machines next time.
refs: #Person1# is a new member who wants to use the machines. Johnson teaches #Person1# to get a card to keep track of the progress and record the suitable weight for each machine. #Person1# stops training as Johnson suggests and will go through the rest of the machines next time.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: It's a program about islam. It's very interesting.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Wow! Banyaknya orang! Where are they and what are they doing?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: They are muslims on a pilgrimage to Mecca. Muslims call this pilgrimage 'haj'.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Muslims believe that every man who is able should go on a haj at least once in his life. Mecca adalah spiritual centre of the muslim faith.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Bila orang muslim solat, they face towards Mecca.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Betul tu. Unfortunately, so many people go on the haj each year that there are often stamped and people get killed.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: I heard about that. The pilgrims harus jalan sekeliling a large, sacred black stone.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: That's right. That's when accidents often happen. The Saudi government tries to limit the number of pilgrims, to reduce the chances of accidents.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Pilgrimages are common in many faiths.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Yes. Kat England, Christian pilgrims might go to Canterbury and many Christians go to the Vatican on pilgrimages.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Kan ada tempat kat France where people go to get healed?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: I think that place is Lourdes. There are many stories of people being healed after visiting there.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Do you think that there is something magical about that place?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Personally. Aku rasa ada orang believe they will be healed and that faith causes a change in their mind that cures them. I don't think place is magical in any way.

summary: #Person2# introduces one program about Islam to #Person1#. They are talking about the pilgrimages of Muslims and people in other faiths.
refs: #Person2# introduces one program about Islam to #Person1#. They are talking about the pilgrimages of Muslims and people in other faiths.

messages.text: Well, Ann, tour hari ni bukan a race. People do it for fitness and fun andtry to better their time setiap tahun.

messages.text: How long will it take to cycle one way, Robin?

messages.text: Agak-agak seven to nine hours for the average cyclists. Cyclist yang bagus boleh habiskan dalam empat jam.

messages.text: Berapa orang will be taking part this year?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: This is our biggest year ever. Kita ada twelve hundred cyclists registered.

messages.text: I doubt they'll block the road when the cyclists start out?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Jangan risau, we've introduced the staggered starts to avoid these problems. Our first group will leave Ottawa at seven o'clock.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Hey Welcome to Berlin, it's great to see you again.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Yeah, good to see you too. Have you been waiting here at the station long?

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Only 15 minutes, but let's get out of this cold and go to my apartment. How are you feeling after that long bus ride?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: It wasn't too bad, it was only 19 hours.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: That's crazy. You could have flown here from London for 60 euros and it would have only taken an hour and a half. Was it really worth all that time just to save a bit of money.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Well, it was a pretty uncomfortable right to be honest. The bus was starting to smell toward the end of it and there was a guy next to me, he was breathing really loudly while he was sleeping. But the reason I took the passwords because it's more environmentally friendly than flying.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: I think it's great that you want to help the environment, but you look so exhausted right now. I just think you should be a little more careful with your health.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Well. I wasn't expecting the bus to be so unpleasant, but you're right. Next time I visit you, I'll probably fly.

summary: #Person2# comes to Berlin to visit #Person1#. They talk about #Person2#'s unpleasant journey on their way back to #Person1#'s apartment.
refs: #Person2# comes to Berlin to visit #Person1#. They talk about #Person2#'s unpleasant journey on their way back to #Person1#'s apartment.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Police in North London are treating as murder the death of a man thought to be in his forties whose body was found in a pedestrian subway in Neasden. The man leading the hunt is Detective Chief Superintendent John Day, who explains what they know of the man's movements in the early hours of this morning.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: What we've learned is the fact that he left the Level One Club, which is a drinking club in Neasden Lane, about 1:30 a.m., and we're trying to account for movements up till 2:15 a. m., because it was about that time he was found by a member of the club, an employee. He was found in the underpass, the pedestrian way, under the North Circular Road. Death was due to multiple head injuries. We understand that there may have been two girls and a man who was drunk in close proximity to the entrance to the subway, who may have seen the man walking in that direction, or any attacker who may have been following him.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: About what time would you think that they were there?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Just after half past one to a quarter past two.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Then in that case the gap you have is really quite short. It's only more or less half a hour or forty minutes.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: In fact, yes, as short as that.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: And how far away from the Neasden underpass was the drinking club?

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: And at the moment you know of no other people in the area whom you want to talk to, other than the drunken man and the two women who were seen with him or near him at some time?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Yes. The club closed at half past one and there may have been other people who left the club who went that way. We understand that there were also minicab drivers parked in the area who may have seen something as well.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: As it is, I take it you haven't been able to identify them.

summary: Detective Chief Superintendent John Day is trying to figure out the murdered man's movements in the short gap between he left the club and got murdered, but he only has three witnesses and hasn't been able to identify more.
refs: Detective Chief Superintendent John Day is trying to figure out the murdered man's movements in the short gap between he left the club and got murdered, but he only has three witnesses and hasn't been able to identify more.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Good morning, thanks for coming. Shall we begin? Why do you want to be a music teacher?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Because I've been always loving music since I was young. And I hope I could have a job that suits my interest.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Do you have a degree in related fields?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Yes, I have a bachelor and a master degree in music and art.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Oh, that's very impressive. What kind of music do you like listening to?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: I like many kinds of music. Sometimes I listen to the music that has fast beat and is lively, like dance music. You know, I go to a disco almost every week. Sometimes it's too loud though. And I love classical music the most. I find it very relaxing. I often listen to Mozart or Bach in the evening after a hard day at work.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: How do you know about classical music?

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Actually, I specialized in classical music for my master study. Classical music is supposed to be good for you brain. Researches suggest that it makes your brain more active. Students who listen to classical music while studying perform better. That's true. There's clear evidence that people who listen to lively music are lively people. Music can influence a person's feeling and character.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Good, I am pretty satisfied with your background. Do you think students should listen to more classical music than others and why?

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Yes. Sometimes students can be stressful. Listening to classical music is helpful in reducing stress. That's why I listen to it in the evenings. I usually play it as background music while I'm cooking or doing other housework.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Okay, I think I've known enough of you. The interview is over.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Oh, by the way. I think I may want to listen to some classical music. Do you have any suggestions?

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: You can find plenty of recording on the internet. You can search and listen to different classical music and see which interests you the most. You can also buy them very cheaply online if you like them.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: That's a good idea. I'll try it.

summary: #Person2# is being interviewed for a music teacher. #Person2# says #Person2# has degrees in music and specializes in classic music. Then #Person2# shares some research about classic music that can make people relaxed. #Person1# is very satisfied with #Person2#. #Person2# gives some suggestions on how to start listening to classical music.
refs: #Person2# is being interviewed for a music teacher. #Person2# says #Person2# has degrees in music and specializes in classic music. Then #Person2# shares some research about classic music that can make people relaxed. #Person1# is very satisfied with #Person2#. #Person2# gives some suggestions on how to start listening to classical music.

messages.text: You mean my hair? You like my hair?

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Uh, I think you know what I mean, Andrew. Do you want me to be honest?

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Okay. Andrew. You've put on, like, a ton of weight since I saw you at Christmas time. What on earth happened to you?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Why are you always so blunt?

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Well, I'm your big sister. I'm ... what am I? Three years older than you, and I can be blunt if I want. Besides, you used to say stuff like that to me all of the time. You used to call me fatso all the time when I was little.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Oh, yeah, well, to be honest, uh ..., I started changing my life .... yesterday.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: What? I've never even heard of the Wafu Diet. What is that?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Ah, it's too difficult to explain. I found information about it in my junk mail the other day ...

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: What? You read your junk mail? No one reads their junk mail.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: ... and I signed up for it, and it only cost $490.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Like every month or every week or ...?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: I didn't check that ... ah, ah, but, but, but, but ... I think ...

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Listen. I think you're getting scammed, and it sounds really stupid, so listen. I'm not fat anymore, so trust me. I ... if you want to lose weight, you need to do it the right way.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Okay, uh, well, look. Look at my running shoes over there.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Andrew. They're still in the box.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Never used. Besides exercise, yeah, exercise is wonderful. It's great, but you also need to learn how to eat right. For example, you need to eat smaller portions. And, and you can't load up your plate with seconds and thirds like you always used to do at the family parties.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Well, okay. I'll just get a bigger plate!

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: . Oh yeah. So, first of all, smaller portions

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Then, you need to make sure you eat a good, well-balanced breakfast first thing in the morning

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: And then you follow that up with smaller meals throughout the day, cause, you know what? If you skip breakfast, then throughout the day, you feel like you need to make up it by overeating at lunch and dinner and lots of snacks.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Anyway, um, oh yeah. Don't eat late at night.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Well, you know a lot of people ... they want a ... they want a late night snake and stuff like that, but a lot of times, that's really, really high-calorie stuff like ice cream and things, and your body's not active to burn it off, so you just store all those calories as fat. You have to throw away ... Oh my gosh!

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: That's all you have in your freezer! You've only got ice cream in here! You're going to have to throw that all away?

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Low cal. No, it's not low-cal. Look right here. Andrew! That's all the food you've got in here is ice cream.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Also, what else are you eating?

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: I mean, seriously. All you eat is ice cream? Oh, oh, oh. Look in your trash. You go to McDonalds every day. Every day you're eating at fast food?

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Okay, you got to cut out the fast food. When you know the manger of McDonalds by name, and he's your best buddy on Facebook, you know that you're going to McDonalds or any fast food place too much.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Uh, this is going to be tough.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Yeah. It probably will be. But you also need to eat a lot of fresh fruits and vegetables.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: cut way back on sugar. No more sugary drinks like those five gallons of Coke you drink every day.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Close enough. Look at the size of those cups! How many times do you refill them?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Oh, this is going to be tough.

summary: Andrew is on the diet according to a junk mail. His elder sister thinks he's scammed and hopes he could listen to her. She suggests he do exercises, eat smaller portions, eat well-balanced breakfast and follow up with smaller meals throughout the day, never eat late at night, throw away ice-cream, cut out the fast food, eat a lot of fresh fruits and vegetables, cut way back on sugar and drink water instead of sugary drinks. Andrew feels this is going to be tough.

messages.text: The green party have no chance of winning an election. The other parties are too big and popular.

messages.text: You're right. But smaller political and pressure groups can often influence large political parties. Any member of parliament can propose legislation and parties and pressure groups can raise awareness

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Most people are not very politically aware. They often don't understand the issues fully.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: That's true. But it's a little strange because the media often reports on political events. You can read about them in newspaper or hear them on tv.

messages.text: Uh, Naa enga irukken? Tsk, hum ...

messages.text: Illa, Naa ... Naa just paathuttu irukken ... well ...

messages.text: Uh, well, actually ... yeah. Um ... Naa science museum ku poganum, but konja nerama epdi poganum nu vazhi theriyama suththitu irukken, and intha ticket machines ah eppadi use panrathuney therila.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Ah, well, just intha button ah press pannunga.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Oh, yeah. And Inga irunthu anga poga, it's a dollar fifty.

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Apo platform number 4 la train eridunga.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Alright. Oh, and ethana nerathukku once intha time la trains varum?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: Usually, oru every 6 minutes ku oru train varum.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Okay. Train la irunthu enga naa eranganum?

messages.author: Person2
messages.text: State Street Station la erangidunga, Inga irunthu three stops.

messages.author: Person1
messages.text: Okay. Enakku purunjiduchu. Unga help ku thanks.
